Look, the Illuminati is not real. The group was founded by a man called Adam Weishaupt in the Kingdom of Bavaria, now a part of Germany, in the late 18th century. It was banned and dissolved by the Bavarian government after less than 20 years with support from the Catholic Church (1776 - 1790). Weishaupt died in exile in 1830. The group never amassed any significant political power. If they had enough power, the government of a small kingdom such as that of Bavaria, wouldn't have been able to ban the group.

They never amassed any power on the world stage and never planned to. [The society's goals were to oppose superstition, obscurantism, religious influence over public life, and abuses of state power. "The order of the day," they wrote in their general statutes, "is to put an end to the machinations of the purveyors of injustice, to control them without dominating them.] This is from Wikipedia.

The group was banned over 200 years ago and it doesn't exist. Ignore all the foolish conspiracy theorists saying the contrary. If there is a group called the Illuminati, it's probably a modern day occult group seeking to reap the fame of the original or maybe some sakawa boys who wanna dupe you.

The Illuminati was a Bavarian political group that advocated the overthrow of hereditary European monarchies. They were founded in 1776 and disbanded in 1785. They only ever had six members. They met in beer halls.

Can you join a group that hasn’t existed for more than 200 years - and when it did exist, only existed in Bavaria? No. No, you cannot.

The group no longer exists, you cannot join it. Anyone who tells you anything different is scamming you.

To correct some misconceptions:

  • The Illuminati does not now, nor did it EVER, consist of “many different groups.”
  • Knowing where a fake group is won’t “put your own life, family, friends and community in jeopardy” because there’s no such thing as the Illuminati.
  • No one is “monitored” by the Illuminati, because the group hasn’t existed for more than 200 years.
  • No member of the Illuminati EVER needed to “prove their loyalty.” At most they only had to buy a round of beer.
  • There are not now nor have there EVER been any need to “make a lot of sacrifices” for the Illuminati.

If you have any questions about the Illuminati, it’s probably best to ask someone who knows the history of the group, rather than some “less said/less known” nonsense…

Apart from the fact that the Illumaniti do not actually exist, and when they did they were a bunch of intellectuals titting about in Bavaria in the 1700s, now we have to address the question of the belief in the power of money to solve everything.

It is often remarked that money makes the world go round. What is not often said though, is that the larger the pile of money, the greater the speed of rotation. This is of course somewhat counter-intuitive as generally adding more mass tends to make things go more slowly, and those who have made a study of this sort of thing, though not yet able to put it on a mathematical framework, are working to the hypothesis that large piles of money somehow act as a form of lubricant that drastically lowers the co-efficient of friction.

However, there are some things that money cannot buy. I’ve seen kids that come from palaces but can’t think their way out of a wet paper bag. On the other hand, I’ve seen kids that come from houses that can barely afford the prices in Happy Shopper but they can do things that make your head spin.

Don’t get me wrong, each side has its complement of dolts. Because all homo sapiens are is a bunch of brighter-than-average monkeys. At the left of the curve, some of them aren’t as bright as the brightest monkeys. You can’t pay for a bridge to learning. It takes a great many years at the coalface and you never, ever stop. Well, you stop when you’re dead, but that’s about it.

Now, secret societies do exist. There’s the Masons. But that really is just titting about with your trouser leg rolled up (and I suspect spanking each other with cricket bats every now and then, which is a benefit since down at Madame Lucy’s House of Exotic Delights they charge a walletful for that), making sure each other get well-paying jobs, and yes, let’s give them some credit since I’ve just labelled them a bunch of nepotistic perverts, doing good works of charity. They don’t control the world. Not even Barnsley Council.

There are too people out there who think they control the world. They do have a nomenklatura and a cadre of apparatchiks and temporarily they do have some influence in the way things are done and affect millions of lesser lives, yes. These people always, at some point, come crashing down to earth again. Ask Louis XVIII. Or Czar Nicholas. Or Tony Blair. Or the Emperor of China. Or Colonel Gadaffi.

In short, both money and power are fleeting. Who was a bigger name in American politics at one time than that of Kennedy? Don’t hear much about them now, do you? So, why would you want to join a secret society, even if they did exist, which they don’t.

I know it’s comforting to think that somebody somewhere has got a plan but the truth of the matter is that if it’s anybody, it’s God. People came from monkeyness, in monkeyness they remain, and in the end to monkeyness they return. No matter how many pretty little bows they tie things up in on the way. Money is a nice tool for getting things done, but it isn’t the right tool for a lot of jobs, and certainly not for your intellectual development. There is no royal road to learning, no shortcut to the acquirement of any art, wrote Trollope. And he was a famous gobshite with a propensity to use a prose style which drives me up the bloody wall and I can never make it ten pages into anything of his without getting irate. You can tell the uberloquacious bastard worked at the GPO, that’s for sure. Eighty-three chuffing words to ask for a cup of tea, there.

Where was I? Oh, yes. No. You can’t pay for intellectual credentials. You have to be judged by your peers and invited. And even then you aren’t going to change the world. Few people manage that. Tull, Newcomen, Watt, Marconi, Armstrong, Tommy Flowers and his Dollis Hill Mob, Wozniak, Gates, Zuckerburg (who frankly creeps me out), and possibly Elon bloody Musk who, as the Texans say, is much more hat than he is cattle but at least there is a solid couple of achievements there that might last. Probably.

I blame the EU. Ursula put der Lucredown.
